description: (verb) From Latin regressus, past participle of regredior (“to go back”), from re- (“back”) + gradior (“to go”).

entries.meaning: The act of passing back; passage back; return; retrogression.
examples: Its bearing on the progress or regress of man is not an inconsiderable question.

entries.meaning: The power or liberty of passing back.
In property law, the right of a person (such as a lessee) to return to a property.

verbs.description: regress (third-person singular simple present regresses, present participle regressing, simple past and past participle regressed)

definitionGroups.group: (intransitive) To move backwards to an earlier stage; to devolve.

entries.meaning: (psychology) To re-develop behavior one had previously grown out of, particularly a behavior left behind in childhood.
examples: Your nightmares stopped when you were eight years old, but after the house burned down, you regressed.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, astronomy) To move from east to west.
(intransitive, medicine) To reduce in severity or size (as of a tumor), without reaching total remission.
(transitive, statistics) To perform a regression on an explanatory variable.
examples: When we regress Y on X, we use the values of variable X to predict those of Y.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To interrogate a person in a state of trance about forgotten elements of their past.
examples: They regressed me, putting me under hypnosis. Then, through the hypnosis, they found out that our car was abducted right off the road and into a craft.
